0: Sniffer dog Tucker uses his nose to help researchers find out why a killer whale population off the northwest coast of the United States is on tKe decline
1: He searches for whale faeces floating on the surface of the water which are then collected for exam ination
2: He is one of the elite team of detection dogs used by scientists studying a number of species including right whales and killer whales
3: Conservation canines are fast becoming indispensable tools for biologists according to Aimee Hurt associate di rector and co founder of Working Dogs for Conservation based in Three Forks Montana
4: Over the last few years though so many new conservation dog projects have sprung up that Hurt can no longer keep track of them all
5: Her organization s dogs and their handlers are fully booked to assist field researchers into 2012
6: Dogs have such a phenomenal sense of smell explained Sam Wasser director of the Center for Conservation biology at the University of Washington in Seattle
7: He has worked with scat detectio n dogs since 199 g
8: Scientists have been using Conservation Canines in their research since 199 g
9: These dogs have enabled them to non invasively access vast amount of genetic and physiological information which is used to tackle conservation problems ar ound the world
10: Such information has proved vital for determining the causes and consequences of human disturbances on wildlife as well as the actions needed to mitigate such impacts
11: The ideal detection dog is extremely energetic with an excessive play dr ive
12: These dogs will happily work all day long motivated by the expectation of a ball game as a reward for sample detection
13: The obsessive high energy personalities of detection dogs also make them difficult to maintain as pets
14: As a result they frequ ently find themselves abandoned to animal shelters facing euthanasia
15: The programme rescues these dogs and offers them a satisfying career in conservation research
